reviewText:
I am the House of Julii.

I am to the North of Italy. I am part of the Glorious Roman Republic, sharing with three other factions; the blue Scorpios (I think) who have decided to take a couple of islands and then the big parts of Africa. The green Brutii, who decided that looking ridiculous would best show the Greeks what's what. And I, wearing fantastically imperial red, who was tasked with sorting out the dirty Gauls.

I quickly began a conquest that would put the Black Templars to shame, sending out army after army, conquering town after town. They tried to resist, but my men were worth two of theirs, and my men outnumbered their three to one. As we came, we took most of them slaves, built up my core towns, built as many temples to convince more people to shag as possible, and continued on our merry murdering way.

Occasionally, the Guals or Brittony or Germans would manage to scrape together an entire army of 2000 people. These were the battles I, and my family, were born for. We smashed together, blood and sword and sinew, as my Velites threw their spears overhead, and cavalry quickly hit them from behind. Few enemies died facing us in the north, many ran and most died with sword wounds in their backs rather than face us.

We tried peace once, and we paid the price with roman lives. When they begged for our mercy, they found only our gladius. We heard the lamentations of their women as they were taken back to mighty Arretium, our capital city. And how it had grown; on the back of slaves and the glory of our men, we raised great arenas and temples to show our glory! We raised great barracks to train our men! We grew the greatest of men to enforce our will! And the north of Europe was stained red with blood; the map of Europe was stained red with our flags.

We found that land ran out quickly; Europa gave way before our bloodlust did, and we turned to look back. We were disgusted with what we saw. Corruption. Weakness. Our supposed equals made peace with the savages, our supposed superiors hide behind the walls of Rome. They whispered of treachery, but we knew weakness and corruption when we saw it. The spineless Scorpios had no trouble gaining the favour of the Senate; spending more time on their knees in glorious Rome than sword in hand over Carthage. The Brutii failed to live up to their brutish name; content with a paltry pile of sand, growing fat and lazy as we had grown lean and numerous in both flesh and glory.

We recalled our armies to home, to the swell of the crowds. They chanted our name, and spat at the mentions of the Senate. All had been united under our banner; did not the Celts and Gauls and Germans and Thrycians alike not bend the knee to the glorious Romans, all beneath the bloody red banner of the Julii? Mars had made his favour clear; he doesn't favour cowards, and Jupiter didn't let the weak rule. We built temples in His Name, and spread his name further than even the diplomats know. All that was left was to follow the glory given to us, under the gaze of the gods and cheers of the people, we marched the final path.

All roads lead to Rome.

reviewText:
RTW has an epic feel.

As of today, this game is nearly eleven years old.  So, the battle graphics are not as crisp as newer titles, the historicity of some units is sketchy (or just made up), and it seems that multiplayer is not smooth in Steam.  Fortunately, none of these mean a thing to me.  The heart of the game is in the grand strategy and the personal narrative.

With over a hundred regions in which to play, the strategic game is where RTW shines. You need to plan where you will expand and where you will defend... and then be ready to adapt when the AI does not do what you expect. You may be the pawn of the Senate and serve at their beck and call.  You might try to expand against the weak.  You can follow the trade routes to gain riches through conquest.  You will find yourself occupying regions merely to stymie your enemies (and your allies). Or you might work your way towards all seven Wonders to reap their benefits.

The twenty factions all fall into one of the major religio/cultural groupings. Some conquered peoples will not like your religion, but a few might. Some conquered peoples will happily accept you as overlord because you share the same cultural values... and the Spanish clans just don't like anyone. Some factions have great infantry, some have cavalry, and some do many things well.  Yet, you can usually find mercenaries (disgruntled locals, rival tribes, or thugs) who might fill the holes in your army.

Yes, most negative reviews harp on about the lag in multiplayer and the poor graphics in battles.  If you need gratuitous violence or managing pixels in a free for all, then watch Mad Max: Fury Road or play League of Legends. If you want to make decisions that will impact your dominion fifty turns down the road, then this game can give it to you.  What kind of temples will you build in each region... or should you let the people keep their native religion?  Will a town become a recruiting station or a cash cow?  When you conquer a region, you'll have to decide to either just incorporate it into your lands as is, relocating half the people by enslaving them, or just slaughtering most of the inhabitants and stealing their goods.... and you'll find yourself using each throughout the campaign, because one size does not fit all.

And guess what?  I don't fight the battles.  If I did, I'd never finish a campaign.  I hit the auto calculation button every time.  Why?  Well... there are a number of positions which you will fulfill in a game.  Benevolent multi-generational spirit guiding your family, governor of a province, Commander in Chief, general of an army, and captain of a unit. Playing all of these breaks the narrative for me... I play the macro game, i.e. the big picture.  I plot and scheme, I build cities, and recruit armies.  Then I send them out into the field.  How they do is up to them.  If they win... great! I must be a genius.  If they lose... nuts. Back to the drawing board.

Two friends of mine, let's call them Doc and Bro, played RTW like this... Doc played the campaign map, i.e. he decided what units were built and where the battles were fought, but Bro fought all the battles.  Doc was the CinC and Bro was the General.  They played two campaigns in three years, but they remember both as epic stories of their teamwork.

In addition to the war... campaign strategy, building armies, transportation of armies, theatres of conflict, fog of war, etc... you'll have to deal with natural disasters, (In one game, a young woman of my family married a promising young fellow, but he died a year later in an earthquake.), piracy, rebellions, brigands, bribery attempts upon your armies, old age, death in battle, adoptions, plagues (stupid unwashed barbarians), and assassination. (In one game, the youngest son of my German leader was sent to subdue Gaul and Hispania. This gave him a command of 10.  I marched him and his elite German veterans across the Alps to conquer Rome... but the Romans assassinated him.  With my hordes leaderless, the Romans proceeded to sieze Gaul and invade Germania.) All of these additional factors help create a unique narrative for each game.

Oh, and when you play as a Roman faction, you'll need to keep an eye upon the Senate... how they view you, how the plebs (the masses) view you, Senatorial missions, and the official Senatorial stance with every other faction. For instance, you may have a great trade agreement with the Egyptians and a low standing with the Senate, but the Sentate demands that you attack Egypt... attacking Egypt will hurt your income considerably, but offending the Senate may cause them to label you as a rebel... what will you do?

Certain events always happen... Aetna erupts and the plague breaks out in Macedonia, but certain other events happen only when certain triggers occur (the Marian reforms), while others, such as floods, are random.  But the big event for Roman players is the Civil War.  At some point the plebs will want you to deal with the Senate and/or at some point the Senate will either have enough of you or become paranoid of your growing power that they'll demand the head of your family to commit suicide.  If you agree, they'll do it every turn until your family ceases to exist.  If you're not ready for war, then you can comply with the Senate for a few years (and prune your family tree of bad apples in the process), but at some point you'll have to stand up to the Senate... at which point you go to war with all other Romans.  Talk about raising your anxiety.... sheesh!

All of your characters really flesh out the narrative... the story of your family.  Spies, diplomats, assassins, admirals, generals, and governors all have character traits that make them who they are.  Some will be drunkards, perverts, and ne'er do wells, while some will be loyal, moral, and cunning.  They'll also tend to generate a following of hangers on, freeloaders, men of honor, mistresses, etc...  For instance, a son might come of age in your family with a command of 3... a natural born general... but on his way to the frontier to defeat the Dacians, his inner circle grows to include a Drunken Uncle and an Actor and they decrease his command ability by 3... Ouch!  He's now a zero...

In the first two Total War games, Shogun and Medieval, you had family members, but not nearly as many as Rome.  So to help you manage them (and for the sheer fun of telling a story), RTW includes a family tree.

The game's not perfect.  The legendary/semi-mythological units can be frustrating and the Egyptians were certainly not using chariots in the second century BC. Naval combat results can make you scratch your head.  Negative income numbers on the campaign map are definitely misleading. There is always the point at which you know you've won even though you may only be forty to seventy percent of the way to the finish... but that's true of a lot of games.

There may be other games out there that have made improvements to the grand strategy game, but I've always found this one to be fun to return to.

reviewText:
Rome: Total War is a strategy game from Creative Assembly and published by SEGA. Rome: Total War is set during the timeline of the Roman Republic to its transition into the Roman Empire.

Rome: Total War gameplay can be overwhelming for newcomers but its not hard to master the gameplay. First you can only play as Rome, choose one of three Roman royal family. You start on the campaign map with some settlement where you can expand it, train troops, train a diplomat and build your empire. You can engage in diplomacy with other faction such as the Greeks, Egypt or Gaul, make alliances or declare war. When it comes to battle, you can choose to auto resolve the battle if you outnumber the enemy or engage the fight in the battlefield where you will command your troops. This is the best part where you command hundreds or thousands of Roman Legion and Auxiliaries support to fight the Greek Hoplites or the barbarian army and watch them kill each other. Each army can be commanded by a general which will improve the army morale and increase the auto resolve chance of winning. Each general has some skill bonuses that can improve army or improve settlement when they become the governor. As General takes part in battle, their skill bonuses will improve.

Rome: Total War is quite addicting to play. When you're done playing with Rome, other faction can be unlocked and then you can play as them. Then you can instead fighting Rome and defeat the greatest empire ever exist in history. The graphics may be old, and some technical issues may occur on newer system, but the game is more than playable. I recommend this.

Rating 8/10

reviewText:
The Total War series has an element of elegance to it. Exploring the ways of historical battle as finely and closely as it does is rare, and only some years after its first installment (Shogun) did the videogame industry begin to shoot similar titles.

After the legendary Medieval, not many people believed that, apart from a change of setting to a different historical moment, a considerable amount of different content would come up. Then Rome shouted: you're wrong.
This game brings pretty much every element of real-time strategy and tactics to the table: city development, troop development and upgrade (besides restoration of battered troops), a ranking system for experienced details that smells pleasantly like Total War spirit, and a turn-based diplomatic conflict and tension only rivaled by the Civilization series, in my opinion.

Rome does have its flaws, mainly related to in-battle bugs and primary AI, but its general brilliance is undeniable. Total War lovers meet RTS lovers in this game, as we witness the rise of Rome from the eyes of three powerful political strata of the Roman Empire (houses Brutii, Julii, and Scipii), besides several pagan tribes from central and eastern Europe - some of which you can control after the main campaign has been finished -, as well as northern Africa. A complete set of compelling diplomatic progress is also displayed in Rome (you can constantly set up family alliances, strengthening the power of military stations in cities you control through the maturing of new generals and governors), as well as completude of technological upgrades, and plurality of maps for different battle strategy tastes, from snowy forests of Northern Germany to Spanish plains to Eastern European rocky hills.

Rome: Total War puts you right into the heat of pre-medieval belli, the moments of Roman rise and fall, the pressure from the outside and from the inside. Intrigues, military management, civil complexities, and territorial tension.

reviewText: Rome: Total War. One of my all-time favorite games. Taking place in the late Roman Republic, you assume control of one of three Roman families vying for power. Depending on which family you select, the Senate will usually direct you against one of three adversaries - the Greeks, the Gauls, or the Carthaginians. Is the Senate demanding you join in on the war against the Macedon, but you'd rather become allies? Go for it! Just make sure you keep a home guard, because Civil War is a constant threat!\n\nIt has been almost ten years since Rome's release. It hasn't aged terribly bad - the AI is somewhat atrocious, the graphics are dated, but the game is still genuinely satisfying. At the price Rome goes for during Steam's seasonal sales, there's really no excuse NOT to give this game a try. If nothing else, it is a taste of nostalgia before these types of games became more like movies and less like free-for-all sandboxes!

reviewText:
Let's start with a confession. When Rome Total War was released I didn't buy it, didn't play it. Turn based sounded boring, I wanted real-time because that was cool. So when did I first play it? After Rome 2 was announced, I wanted to play with the ancient world but release was still months away. Then the release was utter garbage. Thus I turned to Rome Total War.

So lets start with the TL;DR part.
Good: The feel of combat. It's not fast, a bit to slow but formations collide.
Good: Size, this game is huge. Large amount of provinces as well as factions. Improvement over Shogun 2, stuck in Japan.
Good: Atmosphere, Senate missions as Rome, three seperate factions. Lots of different other factions too.
Good: Mods, mods, mods. There some excellent mods out there for this game.

Bad: Graphics, the graphics sure aged. Then again it's an old 3D game, they rarely age well.
Bad: AI, AI isn't the smartest. The game is easily gamed, then again newer Total War's still are.
Bad: Egypt. Egypt was greek at the time, not pharaohs, well not styled like the rulers of old. Just graphics but I'll mention it anyway.
Bad: Resolution, no real widescreen support and no 1080p at all. Highest I can get is 1600x1400.

So should I still get it? Well it's different for sure. I got into it after I played Medieval 2, Empire, Shogun 2 and Fall of the Samurai. I could make the journey back and was pleasantly suprised. On the other hand my main gaming PC wasn't very available at the time and I played mostly on a laptop. So older games was something I was stuck with either way.

Give it a shot if you like ancient history, a slower strategy game and long battles. If you like historical accuraccy give Europa Barborium a spin. From a pure gameplay perspective it has an overwhelming amount of units, recruitment, moving and battles take ages but it's sure authentic.

This is a great game, it has aged but not to much. It's deep but not to deep and I'm sort of sad the path Total War games have been taken lately. Still we can go back to this and I recommend you do that.

reviewText:
Note: I have played this game for embrassingly numerous hours outside Steam, certainly many thousands.

The Total War series revolutionized a strategy genre that was stagnating. After years of the same things over and over again, strategy games with only campaigns and no war, sitting and waiting for this mechanic or that to play itself out, games that made the GUI a bit messier and called it depth, features that just made the same stuff a bit more Heath Robinson and called it progress and innovation, battles where you watched columns of numbers, or 7-8 little RTS guys bip and bop for 30 seconds until the game told you who won... Total War brought in a tactical scope with depth to it, actual battlefields where real time decision-making and some sensible tactical considerations played roles, and where the clash was a grand spectacle. In one fell swoop, this series revitalized the genre, indeed carved out its own genre - strategy games where real time wargaming is actually a thing.

Then, some time into the series, this game - this beautiful, beautiful game came along. Not content with what they'd achieved already, they made a game so good it broke the mould. Not content with creating their own groundbreaking genre, they then pushed further.

It might have aged now, and it isn't such a surprising, groundbreaking thing now as it was back then, and it has its warts and annoyances (like all of the games in the series) but I still have to say that for me, this is possibly the best computer game ever made. Certainly one of the best.

Also, it is a great family game, as long as the subject matter is ok for your tribe, we have had many years of fun out of these games. It is not bloody and gratuitous at all, although obviously war is violent in itself.

There is nothing else that does computer wargaming like the Total War series, and this is the glorious pinnacle of it. 100/10

reviewText:
This game is by far, my favorite game. Hands down, no competition. It is old, but I've yet to see any other strategy game come close to this. The graphics are decent, considering its age. The gameplay is complex enough to not be bored and just steamroll through everything, yet simple enough to actually know how to use every feature this game has to offer.

The game is basically you controlling a faction during the time of the Roman Republic, and trying to become the best nation. Diplomacy is simple and allies will betray you constantly, unless you would just completely dominate them (and even then, they still might attack you!) The AI is pretty simple to defeat, their entire strategy seems to be just throwing all of their units at you and seeing who wins.

The challenges come when you get into the Roman Civil War. This is an in-game event where the 4 roman factions fight each other for control of Rome. Up until this point, you've just been steamrolling through barbarians with your heavy legionnaires. Once the Civil War starts, you're fighting 3 other roman factions (2 of which have just as much land as you if not more, each) and they have the same troops as you. If you're not playing a roman faction then this will never happen, but it's called ROME total war for a reason.

If you're into strategy games, buy this game. Even if you're not, you should at least give it a try. The controls might be difficult to use at first, but the tutorial is very helpful. You will probably lose your first few campaigns, but once you get the hang of the game it will be so much fun.

reviewText:
Rome Total War was in many ways the best that the Total War series had to offer, it was the game that took a giant leap forward and set the standard that it's own developers have yet to break. Despite game breaking bugs and broken promises about modding support Rome Total War still manages to give you a grand experience as you grow your empire towards total domination.

For those who have never played a Total War game it has two distinct elements to it, the first is the campaign map, this is an overview map where you build your cities, train units, send diplomats and assassins to your enemies and friends and move your armies around in a turn based grand strategy style and while it has nowhere near the dept of a true grand strategy game it does the job well enough that you forgive it, especially once you start to touch upon the second, and the most important, major aspect of a Total War game, the battles.

When two armies meet on the campaign map you are taken out of the turn based strategy and thrown right smack in the middle of a real time strategy battle with hundreds or perhaps even thousands of soldiers ready to fight and die. You move your soldiers around in squads of archers, swordsmen, cavalry, etc. Each faction has a semi-unique list of units they can employ, from the various types of Roman Legionaries to the Carthaginian War Elephants to the hilariously historically inaccurate flaming pigs. Each unit has it's own skills and abilities and while there is some level of rock -> paper -> scissors involved, the majority comes down to tactics, sure Spearmen beats cavalry, unless the cavalry happens to be charging them from behind.

The game is pretty too, with a good amount of detail considering the scope of the battles, the soundtrack fits almost perfectly with the mood of the game and sounds of battle are utterly satisfying. Even the load screen are great, each one featuring a different quote from a period persona although a lot of mistakes were made by whoever typed in those quotes.

It is not all roses however, Rome has a number of problems too the first and foremost of which being the same one that continues to plague Total War games to this day. The AI is completely and utterly inept. Whether it is trying to assemble an army by sending individual units walking through your territory one by one, letting you eliminate them piecemeal or displaying it's rather uncanny ability to form a perfect battle line and then break it in half just before engagement letting you flank the enemy at will you can't help but feel that this is somehow below the standards of the rest of the game and in fact modders have proven that making the AI not suicide every battle is indeed possible.

In addition to that rather large issue there is a number of smaller ones, the campaign map is incredibly shallow and while the movement style is a big leap up from Medieval it still feels very arcadey. The squalor bug, or feature, as the developers would call it, whereby all cities automatically revolt if they grow to a certain population size. The lack of full scale modding, although Rome features a bunch of great mods there are certain things you are simply not allowed to do, such as adding more factions to the game. And despite the developers saying it's possible and banning people from their forums who says otherwise, it really isn't possible.

Also the game throws any sense of historical accuracy out the window, from the equipment to the map to the very factions very few things in the game represent the time period accurately, this is something that will bother some people while others will ignore it. For me it only becomes annoying when people take their knowledge from Rome and try to apply it elsewhere.

All in all, Rome Total War is a great game, it set the standard for all Total War Games to come and despite a number of annoying bugs and problems it still remains a great game to this day.

If you've ever dreamed of being an ancient general like Caesar or Hannibal, or conquering the ancient world as the romans did, this is the game for you !

Rome Total War is inarguably the best in the Total War series, with Medieval 2 coming in a close second. This game is a must have for all RTS and Grand Strategy fans!

This game is perfect for a newcomer to the total war series, it's simple and easy to get into but tremendous fun to play.  Don't be discouraged thinking that old games are stupidly hard, with cluttered UI and bad graphics, it's not the case here!

The city management and diplomacy is interesting. The UI is polished and easily understandable.  There's a great unit variety and especially the Roman legions are really interesting. There's nothing like mowing down hordes of barbaric tribes with your Legions. Sure the graphics are outdated but it still looks decent, at least you can crank them up to the max even on an old laptop. Total War Rome looked WAY better in it's age (2004) than how Rome II looks compared to today's standards. There are a huge number of mods, and complete overhauls out there to further enhance the gameplay and graphics.

When you buy the game you also get the Barbarian Invasion DLC included which places the whole game to a completely different aspect. There's also another expansion called Total War Rome Alexander but it's perhaps the most forgettable one in the franchise.

This game is in my personal top 10 of all time, worth every penny if you like strategy games go buy it and I guarantee you won't regret it! I played hundreds of hours of it (I owned a physical copy).

reviewText:
Rome: Total War is the oldest Total War game available on Steam, and can be considered the basis of the rest of the games which followed (although I would totally rebuy Medieval: Total War if they ever added that). In previous games, the overlying board played like a giant Risk board, where you moved armied from province to province, instead of having the entire campaign map laid out and moving your armies to specific locations. This was a DRAMATIC shift for the series, and one which really helped to establish it at something unique from other strategy games.

Like all Total War games that followed, you move your armies around the map to strategic locations in your turn, then the rest of the other players' turns elapse. At any point where two armies meet and fight, the option to autoresolve or fight on a tactical campaign map is provided, which is where the real-time portion of the game takes place.

Rome is also the first game in the series where the armies were polygonal as opposed to sprites, which was a RIDICULOUS feat for graphics at the time. It's still relatively streamlined compared to modern Total War games, but it still stands up to this day. It's an excellent, excellent game, and well worth playing even now, a decade after its release. While I don't personally hold it up as the best example of the series, I know many people who do and I cannot fault their opinions - this is a damn fine game.

Totally addictive.  A great game. If you are looking for something to fill up quite a bit of time for quite a small amount of money this is it.   It took me forty hours or so to get through one campaign, that is win one game.  After finishing a campaign successfully you can pick any of the nations on the map to use.

As for the gameplay yourself you start off with some citystates.  You must develop your cities in order to increase monitary capital, defenses, religion, law and order, sanitation etc. all the while keeping the citizens at a content state.  They can and will revolt and kick you out if they get to dissatified.  You also must recruit a variety of soldiers to defend your cities and conquer other cities and generals.  You build siege weapons, ladders, siege towers, battering rams, or later when you get them elephants to scale or break down walls to take other fortresses and eventually rule the world!

As you can tell there is a bit of a learning curve with  this game.  Save often at first.  With a little bit of patience you can learn to do all I have mentioned and more. reviewText:
They may try, but they will never beat Rome: Total War.

Of course, the game is ageing, and with each new Total War iteration struggling to refine the gameplay it was always going to age somewhat badly. The soldiers which at the time seemed technological marvels now look blocky and cartoony, the campaign map looks less vibrant and more modular, the little portraits, banners and such all look unimpressive and much of the interface seems vaguely unresponsibe, low resolution and unattractive.

But they will never beat this game.

What was Rome Total War? Think of cars coming into a world of carts, think of chocolate coming into a world of porridge. People had dreamed of seeing the vast armies portrayed as 2D sprites in the original Shogun: Total War in glorious full 3D, and this game delivered in every way imaginable. The roman cities were sparkling, shining in the sun, the landscapes were the scale of the real world and the armies were, indeed, massive. The formations looked just as good as you always hoped they would, and things like charges had the very, excellent, feeling that we had all imagined.

Not only that, but the game was deep and huge, with hours upon hours of varied gameplay promised, with any faction we wiped out in one playthrough being available to control in the next campaign - something that Empire: Total War really should have allowed. The (strangely Australian) tutorial woman left nothing to chance, and we never felt out of control, rushed, or under any pressure that was not a direct result of our own actions (all faults that would plague later titles in the series, in my eyes)

The characters were great - real world names popping up here and there, generals increasing in effectivness. Money flowed relatively easily if you were but a little thoughtful about it, and developing more advanced troops was intuitive and straightforward.

In short, this game got everything right. It has just the right mix of gameplay imposition and gamer imposition, input from both sources comign together to create a sandbox empire building experience that could suck you in and satisfied you for tens, hundreds of hours.

Amazing game.

reviewText:
Rome: Total War. So much can be said about this game. For this review I'll feel more comfortable explaining all of the Pro's and Con's I faced when playing this game. Remember, reviews are very subjective so my experience may not match yours. However, that shouldn't discourage you to purchase this title.

Pro's: Right off the bat I'm going to talk about one of the key selling points to this game. The Battles!

Battles in this game highly depend on your strategical and logical thinking. You command hundreds to thousands of soldiers on the battle field. Each having unique properties and abilities. Some troops are purely Missile (Troops that use Bows, Slings and Human Heads), while other troops can be a mix of this. A good example to look at are Skirmishers. These troops throw spears and damage units. When they're ammunition is depleted they go into combat with daggers and swords. However, they are inexperienced at hand to hand combat. These types of setbacks and advantages are what bring out the strategic aspect of Total War. So many possibilities as to how you can fight. It's definitely a well made and balanced system.

The Campaign!

Rome 1 has a phenominal campaign alongside its battles. The campaign map spans from Portugal to the Middle East and Russia. Northern Africa and the UK are also included. There are 21 factions however, only a couple are playable. The only way you can play as other factions is by easilly editing a certain script in Rome 1's files. I reccomend doing this as it gives you more options and various ways to make the campaign different. Each faction owns settlements in their unique areas. These can be profited off of to fund your army and other buildings to improve your empires happiness and what you can train in certain settlements. For example, the Carthaginians have access to War Elephants. These beasts can tear through any troop easilly. The only problem is you can't train them during early game as you need certain stables to do so.

Cons: The AI!

First of all, let me explain my position on the AI, It's not terrible at all, especially for a game made in 2004. However, it still needs to be adressed. In a game with a battle system that is dependant on strategy, well programmed AI is essential for such a mechanic. The AI in this game does fail to do so at times. Keep in mind though, the amount of times that such a problem occured is very miniscule. During sieges my Cavalry would sometimes decide to take the least logical route to get a to a certain point. Instead of going through an easy passage, they go to where all my infantry is and try to run through the hoardes of enemies. As long as you can correct them (Which can be done with one right click) this wont be a huge problem but, timing in Total War plays a big part in strategies. It may seem like I am nitpicking but, once you play this game you'll understand the importance of the AI.

Final Verdict: Do I recommend this game? ♥♥♥♥ yeah I do! This game is amazing and I will always love it to death. Especially considering how it was made in 2004. In fact, I would even say that this game out performs Rome 2 (That game is a huge mess that I don't care to explain right now).

I give this game 10 Roman Soldiers outta ♥♥♥♥ing 10. Also keep in mind, this comes with an expansion pack.

reviewText:
Rome Total war is a rare breed. A realistic RTS game without the chaos of real life interfering with it. Historically, this game is fairly accurate, and the Roman fighting style lends itself to more user friendly battles. And here is where the game is such a drastic improvement on the previouse titles in the series.

Organised Chaos
Whether it is by phalanx or testeudo, the battles are a lot more organised than its predecessors. Battles are based on your ability to organise, coordinate and react to the adversity, more than the troops at your disposal. Gone are the morale sapping archers on the hill top and heavy cavalry charge from Medieval TW2 - Rome brings you a more balanced feel to the battle, even if it is elephants vs peasants.

Macro, not micro management
What I like most about Rome (and where they seem to have strayed from the path in more recent releases) is that these are strategy simulations, not population management games. The management evironment is simple and straight forward, the interface is both familiar and intuititve while still giving you the ability to go into more detail if those damn peasants insist on revolting every turn.

Rome is a great game to either pick up and play or delve into in for days on end. Rest assured there is a battle around every corner, usually where you least suspect it.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I must begin by stating that Rome: Total War was the first and so far the only Total War game I have played.

Total War is an exciting and very cerebral strategy game, that tasks you with not only rallying your troops and commanding them in battle but also governing your multiple cities along with it's inhabitants and the political relationships with other factions.

The main campaign plays like a turn-based board game, where each player makes their choices and then skips, allowing others to make their moves. The objective is to take over the world.

Managing your settlements is the slow paced portion of the game but still varied, as you need to satisfy your people while also recruting and positioning your military in order to accomplish your goals. You also need to be wary of what other factions feel towards you and your movements, as having allies might make a critical difference.

When your troops meet other troops in the battlefield, whether it was you who attacked or your opponent is when there is the option to combat them manually. You take control of large armies, going up to to the hundreds or thousands depending or your settings. Controlling this massive number of soldiers is easy and intuitive and the variety of available units allow the combat system to provide you with multiple options. Each unit has its strenghs and purposes and the overall combination of troops you decide to take to battle make all the difference in the world.

I can't recommend this game enough to any player who enjoys strategy or military games.

reviewText:
Developer: The Creative Assembly   Publisher: Activision   Release Date: 22.09.200

Played On: (Various but most recently)
Nvidia GTX 760
AMD FX 6300 3.5Ghz
8GB RAM

(Upto several hundred hours to complete depending on faction, difficulty level and campaign length chosen).

Where to start with Rome Total War? First released back in September 2004 the game recently reached it's tenth anniversary. I've played it on and off since release and the recent anniversary prompted me to go back and play through it again. It's a game that mostly stands up to the test of time for me and well worth playing today. I didn't play the Barbarian Invasion expansion included in the Steam edition as it's quite a distinct entity that should be reviewed in it's own right.

Like all games in the Total War series there are two elements; the campaign map where you manage your empire, build cities, recruit units, move armies etc and the battle map, where you fight battles in real time. This gives the game some great depth and whilst you can auto-resolve battles this can be a bit hit and miss and you'll want to fight them yourself to get the best results. The Imperial Campaign is the main game mode where you can choose from a number of different factions and play through either a short or long campaign with prescribed victory conditions and different difficulty settings. There is a decent tutorial to ease you into things and plenty of advice is available throughout both with the optionn to turn it off for veterans.

The Imperial Campaign is backed up by being able to fight custom battles where you choose the map, faction etc and Historical Battles which recreate a number of famous battles of the era such as Hannibal's invasion of Italy and the Battle of the Teutoberg Forest. You can also play online against other players but this wasn't something I did.

The main campaign has a good deal of depth and each of the factions has different styles, units, cities and starting points which offer a wide variety of challenge. Playing as the Romans is the initial starting point and they are divided into three factions which compete against other and have some additional mechanics to account for including the Senate of Rome, the Marius Reforms and some other suprises which I won't spoil. Rome also generally has the strongest units and buildings which can make things somewhat straightforward for an experienced player. However a lot of the late game units of other factions more than match them and playing the campaign as Eygpt, Carthage, the Britons or others is very enjoyable.

The mechanics of the campaign map are very broad and offer a wide variety of tactical options to pursue; bribery, assassination and spreading plagues amongst them. I played through on the very hard settings which I'd reccomend any veteran Total War player to do and the campaign offered a good challenge with interesting scenarios and incidents along the way. Whilst my progress was steady I wasn't able to steamroll the AI into the ground within a few turns. I did play as Eygpt who are one of the easier non Roman factions to play but still a challenge later in the game.

The battle map is probably the slightly weaker side of the game and whilst some battles, particularly sieges, can be a bit difficult or frustrating, most are straightforward affairs if you have assembled a balanced army and have a relatively comprehensive grasp of the tactics to use. However the various factions armies all have different strengths or weaknesses and there isn't the rock, paper, scissors situation you see in some games. The Roman armies have the strongest armies as a general rule of thumb but other factions e.g. Eygpt, Germania have some very good units too and what works with one may not work at all with another.

I've not mentioned performance or graphics at all as the game is ten years old and there generally shouldn't be any issues nor will it look fantastic.

I'd also take a moment to mention the additional content available online from Europa Barborum and a couple of other sites. These add a huge amount to the game and are well worth a look if you want to take things further after playing the main game.

Overall I'd definetely reccomend playing this if your a fan of the Total War series and I also feel its a good starting point for the series as whole. Those interested in the era itself will certainly find it enjoyable.

reviewText:
This game is on my Top 5 Games of All Time List.

Let's start with the presentation. This Games graphics are out dated, but the attention to detail and polish are abundant. Nothing was more satisfying then watching my cavalry charge send individual men flying. The world map is kind of bland, but you have a pretty good idea of what the terrain is. All of the cities are (or were) real cities, and many you may already know of. This game is a very well researched game. There are many historical troop types and landmarks. I can't even imagine how much time was put in to making this game as historically accurate as possible.
Overall, this is a well-presented game.

Now let's look at gameplay. This games battle system is hands down the best I have seen in any RTS ever. The attention to detail is astounding. Certain troops counter others, this is in other games. However, different formations and tactics can turn the tables on your so-called counters. You can be a regular Cesar if you play your cards right. The AI is not the sharpest tool in the shed, especially when it comes to troop movement. I have missed a table-turning oppurtunity in many a battle due to a units slow response or incorrect followthrough of an order. It could be said that this makes the game more realistic, but that doesn't make it any less frustrating. The game can be played in single or multiplayer player mode. Single player has three functions: Campaign, Custom battles, and Historical battles. The Campaign can be played as one of the three Roman factions at first and later other factions. Not every faction can be played as-at least not in th vanilla-which is a shame as many unique factions were left out. The campaign takes place over a world map as you and the other factions take turns building and managing an empire. The campaign is extremely immersive. Players personalities are reflected in how they play the game. I can be impatient, but I also am a procrastinator. As a result, I would impatiently blitz one enemy, then stand around repelling the attacks of another. The goals of the game are dependent on what type of campaign tou chose. A short one has small goals while a long one has large. Overall the campaign is the best part of the game. The custom battle option is fun for experimenting with new tactics or just goofing around. It is not something you will spend a ton of time on though. The Historical battles are just that, battles from history. They put you in the shoes of real ancient commanders in battles that actually took place. They're fun, but not very replayable. The multiplayer is the second best function of the game. It allows you to play online in battles with other players. The type of battles vary, from sieges to free-for-alls. There are even some historical battles exclusive to multiplayer. Overall, the multiplayer is great for when you want a change of pace.

Over all, this game has a good presentation, pays attention to detail, and is highly immersive, the best ten bucks you'll ever spend. 9.5/10

PC is a Win7-64bit with all the bells and whistles and up-to-date drivers but yet the performance of the game stutters and suffers after about an hour in play to where it takes about 20 seconds to click a menu button. Googling some updates or at least some methods to try to solve this problem...no results. I'm honestly disappointed at how badly optimized this game is for Win7. Your experience may vary.

Good
- Total War series. Everything you ever wanted to be the ruler of Rome and pounding barbarians into dust while bowing to the Senate.
-Unit scale is ridiculously well imagined and with proper planning - you can have some pretty large battles.
-All the mods you could shake a stick at in Workshop or mod communities.
-Replay value for each race/city is phenomenal.

Bad
- Badly optimized for Win7
- Random stutters and crash-to-black. Save often.
- With no balance mods, it's pretty easy for the micromanage to get out of hand to where you need to hire and fire peasants to transfer population from one city to another. Do your reading and listen to the advice on how to manage LARGE cities.

Oldie but good but buyer beware. Be prepared to suffer a bit.

I spend a majority of my strategy gaming with two games: Rome: Total War and Civilization V (I have maybe 250+ hours offline in RTW). Why do I mention this? Because I have to say that while Civ V is a better game (though not by much), I have never found a game more masterfully put together than Rome: Total War. You might be the nicest person ever, but by the end of a campaign you might as well be ranked as the world's #1 sociopath, for you will be driven to crush every rebellion and consolidate the world under the mighty grip of your imperium. The aesthetic, feel, music, all for the glory of arguably the greatest empire ever created is emulated to absolute perfection.

And that's 10 YEARS after the game has been released. The most epic, enthralling, massive strategy game you'll ever get your hands on.

Only issues involve possible compatibility problems. Other than that, you're paying $10 for hundreds of hours of triumphant conquest. An absolute must buy.

reviewText:
This game is on my Top 5 Games of All Time List.

Let's start with the presentation. This Games graphics are out dated, but the attention to detail and polish are abundant. Nothing was more satisfying then watching my cavalry charge send individual men flying. The world map is kind of bland, but you have a pretty good idea of what the terrain is. All of the cities are (or were) real cities, and many you may already know of. This game is a very well researched game. There are many historical troop types and landmarks. I can't even imagine how much time was put in to making this game as historically accurate as possible.
Overall, this is a well-presented game.

Now let's look at gameplay. This games battle system is hands down the best I have seen in any RTS ever. The attention to detail is astounding. Certain troops counter others, this is in other games. However, different formations and tactics can turn the tables on your so-called counters. You can be a regular Cesar if you play your cards right. The AI is not the sharpest tool in the shed, especially when it comes to troop movement. I have missed a table-turning oppurtunity in many a battle due to a units slow response or incorrect followthrough of an order. It could be said that this makes the game more realistic, but that doesn't make it any less frustrating. The game can be played in single or multiplayer player mode. Single player has three functions: Campaign, Custom battles, and Historical battles. The Campaign can be played as one of the three Roman factions at first and later other factions. Not every faction can be played as-at least not in th vanilla-which is a shame as many unique factions were left out. The campaign takes place over a world map as you and the other factions take turns building and managing an empire. The campaign is extremely immersive. Players personalities are reflected in how they play the game. I can be impatient, but I also am a procrastinator. As a result, I would impatiently blitz one enemy, then stand around repelling the attacks of another. The goals of the game are dependent on what type of campaign tou chose. A short one has small goals while a long one has large. Overall the campaign is the best part of the game. The custom battle option is fun for experimenting with new tactics or just goofing around. It is not something you will spend a ton of time on though. The Historical battles are just that, battles from history. They put you in the shoes of real ancient commanders in battles that actually took place. They're fun, but not very replayable. The multiplayer is the second best function of the game. It allows you to play online in battles with other players. The type of battles vary, from sieges to free-for-alls. There are even some historical battles exclusive to multiplayer. Overall, the multiplayer is great for when you want a change of pace.

Over all, this game has a good presentation, pays attention to detail, and is highly immersive, the best ten bucks you'll ever spend. 9.5/10

reviewText:
Possibly the best TW game on the market. It may just be me viewing it through nostalgia-tinted lenses, but this game definitelly surpassed the competition in my book.

Pros:
- Good unit variety, building variety, and so on.
- Far more colorful and vibrant than later entries.
- Good variety of civilizations.
- Decent dificulty curve.
- Replayable to almost infinity due to variety of strategems and civilizations.
- Decent modding community and re-works through dedicated websites.

Cons:
- Realism slightly lacking.
- Some balance issues in multiplayer (barbarians lack morale, phalanx beats any other unit one-on-one etc.).
- Poor diplomacy.
- Community has partially moved on to Medieval II and later, meaning less mods and reworks to add replayability that    otherwise.
- Graphics slightly dated.

In short, the game has much to reccomend it. The main complaint I find is that the game hasn't aged well compared to others, that the graphics are out of date etc. While some have a point, the old graphics have a certain charm and don't detract from the gameplay one bit. In fact, I take that as a point in their favor as it means that older systems can run the game without frying from the effort.
Buy it. You won't regret it one bit.

reviewText:
I came, I saw, I conquered!

Played it since my teen years, bought and played it again. Choose a Roman family, rise in status, fight barbarians, and seize power in Rome herself. Or you could be a barbarian heathen. Easily one of my favorite games in the series and one of the best RTS games of all time.

The only problem perhaps is the autoresolve battle AI seems to leave a lot to be desired. However; if you wanted a turn based game I recommend The Republic of Rome Tabletop game (playable by your lonesome but better with friends you aren't afraid to lose) or your favorite Civilization. The Historical inaccuracy of certain aspects is also fairly blatant but it is forgiven due to the game being more about cinematic sword and sandal warfare than a rough simulation of historical events for that I recommend something by Paradox Interactive.

The game's strenghts lie in it's great battle system and it's fascinating overworld of intrigue. If you want a hardcore tactics game it can be that but there is also an arcade mode for people who just want to watch the sword fights but do not wish to get heavily involved in tactical movement.

This is a game I could recommend for anyone with even a passing interest in this period in history. The phoenicians are waiting to meet you on the field of battle.

The battles are fantastic to play, the game is challenging to play, if you play certain factions, and fun to see a faction that was wiped out by the Roman imperilaists in our history, to suddenly lick Carthaginian sandal in your game. If there are any flaws in this game, it is these; stupid stacked armies (several generals with up to 30 or more units), overpowered factions and historical inaccuracy.  The stupid stacked armies are a constant menace, especially  if you invade Rome, so be ready for that. Another one is overpowerded factions. The one in particullar is Egypt. reviewText:
I must begin by stating that Rome: Total War was the first and so far the only Total War game I have played.

Total War is an exciting and very cerebral strategy game, that tasks you with not only rallying your troops and commanding them in battle but also governing your multiple cities along with it's inhabitants and the political relationships with other factions.

The main campaign plays like a turn-based board game, where each player makes their choices and then skips, allowing others to make their moves. The objective is to take over the world.

Managing your settlements is the slow paced portion of the game but still varied, as you need to satisfy your people while also recruting and positioning your military in order to accomplish your goals. You also need to be wary of what other factions feel towards you and your movements, as having allies might make a critical difference.

When your troops meet other troops in the battlefield, whether it was you who attacked or your opponent is when there is the option to combat them manually. You take control of large armies, going up to to the hundreds or thousands depending or your settings. Controlling this massive number of soldiers is easy and intuitive and the variety of available units allow the combat system to provide you with multiple options. Each unit has its strenghs and purposes and the overall combination of troops you decide to take to battle make all the difference in the world.

I can't recommend this game enough to any player who enjoys strategy or military games.

reviewText:
Rome: Total War is a great game. You know this game came out in 2004 and twelve years later this game managed to heavily impress me. From the small part of diplomatic relations to the absolute massive battle scenes, the game just immediately sucked me in. Now the Total War games had never really been a big thing to me up until this moment so I was just a bit dubious about how much this game would appeal to me, but I am a history buff and I was trying to find a way to spend the summer so I picked it up during the sale. What I found was an actually really good game that managed to combine the turn base parts with the real time strategy.

The game as said is split into two types of strategy. The first part is map screen. From here you manage your settlements and your armies. You can upgrade your towns and recruit new units. From here you can also send out your diplomats to other factions in order to institute trade agreements and forge alliances for wars. The diplomats have actually quite a bit that they can discuss with the other factions. You can make demands such has making them hand over a territory or you can create a trade agreement that can help your income or just allow them military access to other parts of the world. Another thing that impressed me is that they can reject your offer and make counter offers. This really does feel like an actual negotiation rather than just a basic “I declare peace or war thing.” One thing I’m going to say though is that there is a severe problem with the lack of anything to really during peace time. In the end though the map screen is fantastic turn based strategy.

Now as for the actual battle screens it is one the greatest parts of the game. The sieges and the battles are just so massive that it is impossible to be swept away by it. The fights aren’t too complicated. It doesn’t take long to figure the strengths and weaknesses and of each unit. Just know when to charge and how to flank the enemy and that’s rather easy to pick up. What makes it really work though is just the basic ability to pause the game and figure out your positions and where each unit should go. This takes a lot the panicking and stress out of other strategies that usually takes me out of most strategy games. The units are widely varied and it is rather cool to see the progress of your units to much more powerful troops.

In the end what really sells the game is just the absolute scale it has. The game just feels massive and every advancement you do makes you feel more powerful. Some might say that the effects don’t look good and to those people I say they need to shut it. The game looked amazing back in the day and still looks line today. I don’t care if we can’t see every pimple on the soldiers they look fine. As for the multiplayer I don’t know what it’s like. I am not interested in it, but if you are then check it out. Rome: Total War is a game that everyone should check out if you are interested in history or if you think you might be interested in the game.

Overall this is a great game and its only minor things that prevent this game from being perfect.

I'd rate this 9.5/10

reviewText:
If you haven't played a Total War, game before, and even if you have, olden but golden Rome: Total War is no let down.

Based during the age when ancient empires were being built, RTW is both a RTS and TBS in one game.

The Campaign mode(TBS) allows you to take control of a historical civilization and take its humble roots and create an empire. Improve and manage your economy, infastructure, military, taxes, and more. Quell uprisings and keep your people happy. Lash out upon the world: wage war and wield clever diplomacy to accomplish your goals. Take on the world all at once or one piece at a time: create your empire as you feel fit!

When engaging enemy forces for battle in Campaign and when playing Multiplayer(RTS), utilize a variety of faction-unique units to dominate your opponents! There are many, many playstyles to fit your taste; no one strategy is going to be your all-time winner, though some playstyles may be more comfortable for you. These battles can range from petty skirmishes to all-out conflict. No one battle is ever the same.

The graphics are decently good, the gameplay is superb, all in a single package. The only downsides lay in occasional multiplayer trolls and that the RTS combat can be a bit overwhelming/arcade-like since it can be very fast-paced at times. Get used to that, and you have yourself a wonderful game.

10/10

reviewText:
Rome: Total War is a great game. You know this game came out in 2004 and twelve years later this game managed to heavily impress me. From the small part of diplomatic relations to the absolute massive battle scenes, the game just immediately sucked me in. Now the Total War games had never really been a big thing to me up until this moment so I was just a bit dubious about how much this game would appeal to me, but I am a history buff and I was trying to find a way to spend the summer so I picked it up during the sale. What I found was an actually really good game that managed to combine the turn base parts with the real time strategy.

The game as said is split into two types of strategy. The first part is map screen. From here you manage your settlements and your armies. You can upgrade your towns and recruit new units. From here you can also send out your diplomats to other factions in order to institute trade agreements and forge alliances for wars. The diplomats have actually quite a bit that they can discuss with the other factions. You can make demands such has making them hand over a territory or you can create a trade agreement that can help your income or just allow them military access to other parts of the world. Another thing that impressed me is that they can reject your offer and make counter offers. This really does feel like an actual negotiation rather than just a basic “I declare peace or war thing.” One thing I’m going to say though is that there is a severe problem with the lack of anything to really during peace time. In the end though the map screen is fantastic turn based strategy.

Now as for the actual battle screens it is one the greatest parts of the game. The sieges and the battles are just so massive that it is impossible to be swept away by it. The fights aren’t too complicated. It doesn’t take long to figure the strengths and weaknesses and of each unit. Just know when to charge and how to flank the enemy and that’s rather easy to pick up. What makes it really work though is just the basic ability to pause the game and figure out your positions and where each unit should go. This takes a lot the panicking and stress out of other strategies that usually takes me out of most strategy games. The units are widely varied and it is rather cool to see the progress of your units to much more powerful troops.

In the end what really sells the game is just the absolute scale it has. The game just feels massive and every advancement you do makes you feel more powerful. Some might say that the effects don’t look good and to those people I say they need to shut it. The game looked amazing back in the day and still looks line today. I don’t care if we can’t see every pimple on the soldiers they look fine. As for the multiplayer I don’t know what it’s like. I am not interested in it, but if you are then check it out. Rome: Total War is a game that everyone should check out if you are interested in history or if you think you might be interested in the game.

reviewText:
*WARNING : LONG (But detailed) REVIEW

Where to start with Rome Total War? This game is like Sid Meier’s Civilization but more focused on , as the title would suggest , Total War. So, enough beating around the bush.

Pros

This game is absolute genius. Its historically accurate , apart from the part when you , the player , take 100 percent of the area near Rome. The game notifies you when something like a flood or the Pompeii eruption occurs around the same time (I have no clue if Pompeii makes an appearance in the game. I've never gotten far enough). Another great part are the wars. There are , I believe , 3 types of fighting : Army to Army , Army to Town or City , and Fleet to Fleet. Army to Army is a standard type of fighting. Two armies on opposite sides of a field where there will be a fight to the death. This is challenging for me due to all the open space but to others it may be easier. Army to Town or City is where an army is trying to take a town or city by either maintaining a successful siege , starving the enemies inside, or forcefully invading by making Siege Towers , Ladders , Rams , and / or other breaching equipment. Either way , If successful , the army and their faction will then take and rule the captured city. Technically this is a con but , Fleet to Fleet is just borderline impossible , at least for me. In this type of battle, two fleets fight each other on the unrelenting sea. This can be especially dangerous if your ship attacked is a transport ship carrying YOUR ABSOLUTE BEST TROOPS. If this transport ship loses the battle , every man aboard will die. However , there is a fantastic feeling when you successfully take down an army , general , town , or even 1 of 20 factions.

Cons

This game is anything but perfect. For starters , the battle screen. Before each battle , a screen pops up describing the soon starting skirmish along with 3 buttons : Flee and Retreat , Auto Resolve Battle , or Go to Battle Screen and fight the enemy yourself. Tip : Pick Auto Resolve. Fleeing is for Benito Mussolini and good luck trying to figure out the Battle Screen controls. The camera is awful. If you want to move the camera right there is a chance that you could end up looking at the ground. Along with that , you cant simply tell your archers to fire on an enemy. There's this whole process of moving them into position and it's just not worth it. Using a faulty controller to play Mortal Kombat while making a space station in Kerbal Space Program with your toes is easier than taking on an army. Its hard to explain but don't fight in the battles. Another con is the fact that the game goes through almost phases. One minute you have more generals than any other faction with more gold than Scrooge McDuck and another you are losing towns to rebels because of dying Governors without enough cash to fight back , let alone buy half a particle of dirt. This second phase is the main reason I can't get a single faction. The game gives you about 255 years to conquer all factions but even Alexander the Great couldn't win.

Summary

Challenge - 8/10
Replayability - 8/10
Battles - 6/10
Price - Rome Total War - Worth It
Rome Total War Collection - Yes if Previous Fan
Rome Total War Master Collection - Nope
Rome Total War Grand Master Collection - Not even if you are Bill Gates

Verdict - Buy

reviewText:
Rome Total War A great game despite it's age.

Graphics 4 of 10

It's a really old game and the first total war game with 3D units instead of animated 2D sprites so you can't expect much in the way of graphics. and what you expect is what you get.

Learning curve (the lower the number the less learning curve there is) 5 of 10

The tutorials are good and the game is fairly simple to get into. This game has some learning curve for those who have never played any other RTSes but for those who have played other RTSes before they will have no problem getting into this game's controls.

Gameplay (on the battlefield) 7.5 of 10

Pros.

+Siege battles are very fun and challenging without being too hard.
+Land battles are Fun and tactical without being too hard.
+The AI is very good for a game of this age and can keep up with human opponents.

Cons

-some units are a bit over-powered such as elephants.
-some units are completely worthless unless under very specific circumstances such as the incendiary pigs that are only effective against elephants and have a tendency to kill more of your own people then the enemy’s that are killed due to the attack.and they do the same thing that a barrage of fire arrows from your archers could do.

Overall the land battles are very fun to play and are even better if you can find a human opponent to play with (CA recently migrated this game to steam due to the gamespy shutdown.)

Gameplay (Grand campaign) 4.5 of 10

Pros.
+can be very fun when everything works well in tandem.

Cons
-Very dated
-It is nigh imposable to keep your budget in check when at war.
-diplomacy is clunky
-auto-resolving battles tends to end with your army losing a battle that anyone could win when controlling the units themselves.

Overall the campaign is good at times and really bad at others.

Overall 7 of 10.

Rome Total War is a game of two qualities; on one hand the battles are great and fun to command, on the other side the campaign is clunky, and not all that great at all. The good does outweigh the bad however. I completely recommend this game as custom and historical battles circumvent the horrid campaign and go to what is great about Rome Total War the combat.

reviewText:
If you bought this to play multiplayer, ignore my not recommended and buy it immediately, as there is no other option for reliable online multiplayer at this point.

If you're looking to play the singleplayer, DON'T get this version. Buy it on disc from a retailer or online, or torrent it. Why do you ask? In returning multiplayer to this game with steamworks, which I applaud CA for doing, they completely destroyed the performance of the game somehow. No clue how they manage to mess up something so simple, but I have about 100% worse performance with the steam version of the game compared to the older, gamespy version. Another thing is that 99% of mods aren't compatible with steam Rome Total War so you're going to have trouble playing your favourite overhauls with this. Serious FPS trouble with a i7 2600k and GTX 960 on MEDIUM settings, i'm talking drops to 10 FPS in not even remotely huge battles. Unacceptable. I get a almost smooth 60 in similar conditions on my disc copy.

Pros -
Multiplayer is returned

Cons -
Absolutely terrible performance for most people after the patch
Incompatibility with most mods.

reviewText:
As a newcomer to the Total War series, I must express just how enthralled I am by the gameplay of Rome: Total War. It is an impressive strategy game that lets you live out those dreams of amassing a large army. Now these armies can be massive, carrying at least 1,200 soldiers, and don't even get me started on the reinforcements. However, it's not just a mere 'pick up and play' sort of game. This is a game that requires thinking, as a turnbased strategy game. You start off with a faction in the imperial campaign, where you are then given a large map of Europe that is populated with other factions of that time, such as the Greek, Egyptians, Gauls, Spanish, and many more.

It is up to you to conquer Europe and extinquish all other factions from the competition. You can also choose to become allies with a few of these factions, if you want. The diplomacy feature in this game provides heaps of options, from trade rights with other factions, to extortion, or you can tell other factions to attack your rivals.

Each faction has its own economy, but I won't get into that. Admittedly, I'm not very good at this part. This requires constructing certain buildings to improve income, such as shrines to Jupiter or crops. You can choose to have each settlement have its own taxation. But set it too low, and your citizens may revolt and start an uprising. This is a game that requires lots of patience, and your experience should not be rushed. But there is no joy greater than conquering that final Spanish settlement, sending hundreds of infantry troops to slaughter them, while your archers lie back, and bring fire to the various buildings until finally, you have wiped their existence from the face of the Earth.

Overall, Rome: Total War is a thrilling experience that you'll find yourself investing many many hours in. Oh, did I also mention that you can play historical battles that took place in real life? Or if that sounds too boring, you can create your own custom matches.
